item.title: Woojer Vest 4 Review‚ÄîNew Generation, Same Great Feeling
item.content:encoded:
Woojer is back with another iteration of the Vest, an innovative haptic device that allows you to feel the games you play. It‚Äôs a somewhat comical device at first blush that reveals itself as something quite impressive on use, and having used the Woojer Vest 3 a year ago, I can attest to the Woojer Vest 4 being an evolution of sorts.

With the Woojer Vest 4, users can secure punchy haptic feedback from any audio experience, but it‚Äôs marketed much more for gaming. That‚Äôs where I connected with the Woojer Vest 4, linking up with some pulse-pounding games to get the most out of this device.

Is the Woojer Vest 4 worth it? Find out in this snapshot review.

Is The Woojer Vest 4 Any Good?

I was very familiar with Woojer, having used the Vest 3 for many hours across desktop and VR gaming experiences. It was a seamless transition into the Vest 4, which takes on mostly the same form and function but boasts a few changes. I noticed that it felt more comfortable to wear, despite there being few differences in the makeup of the Vest itself.

As I mentioned, the Woojer Vest 4 might look funny at first glance, but there‚Äôs a lot of clever technology lurking under the surface. This haptic device boasts six transducers that offer immensely powerful and physical feedback when playing games.

In case you‚Äôre unfamiliar with the concept, the Woojer Vest 4 offers physical and haptic feedback in collaboration with the sound emitted from your games, music, and movies. It takes an input and cleverly translates that into vibration and shocking feedback, allowing you to feel, at multiple points around your body, the sound that you‚Äôre hearing.

I was eager to use the Woojer Vest 4 in a few rounds of Battlefield 6, so I connected the device to my PC and linked it with my Astro A50 headset and felt every gunshot, explosion, and rumble of tank tracks.

If there‚Äôs one complaint I have about the Woojer Vest 4, it‚Äôs that the latency is a bit off-putting for reflexive gameplay, and even the in-built low-latency mode that can be activated via the Woojer app doesn‚Äôt change much.

That being said, it wasn‚Äôt a deal-breaker. The Woojer Vest 4 is truly a one-size-fits-all device, and it even accommodated my much larger frame for several hours (note: battery life is advertised as 10 hours maximum). If you play VR in tandem with the Woojer Vest 4 (like I did), you‚Äôll get a little toasty under the device, but it‚Äôs designed to be as breathable as possible.

If you‚Äôve never seen or used a Woojer Vest, you‚Äôll quickly get to grips with the Vest 4. It‚Äôs easy to use, comes with handy start-up guides, and has an app with a clean UI that makes it a wonder to use. The front-facing control unit is easy to reach, there‚Äôs a nice spot of RGB lighting, and the inputs are tactile.

There are so few things I found that turned me off from the Woojer Vest 4. Even the price point has come down from the near $500 heights of the Woojer Vest 3. It‚Äôs now floating around $340, which is more comfortable.

If you‚Äôre a VR fan and want to make your experiences much more immersive, I‚Äôd say the Woojer Vest 4 is an easy buy. If you‚Äôre a console or desktop-based gamer, it‚Äôs perhaps less worthwhile, and if you‚Äôre interested in getting the vest for movies or music, I‚Äôd probably suggest reconsidering that decision.

Let me know on the Insider Gaming Discord server if the Woojer Vest 4 sounds like your kind of technology.

item.title: Sound Blaster Katana V2X Soundbar Review
item.content:encoded:
The Sound Blaster Katana V2X ‚Äògaming soundbar‚Äô ticked more than a few boxes for me. It was punchy, easy to use, and it had a tasty splash of RGB that made it a tantalising pick for any gamer. When I was putting together my Katana V2X review, I put this two-part soundbar through its paces, and I‚Äôm pleased to say that it impressed me in every aspect.

The Sound Blaster Katana V2X from Creative is the culmination of decades of work in the audio space, and it‚Äôs a compact yet powerful thing that looks great and works with just about any device you connect to it.

Read on to scope out my full review of the Sound Blaster Katana V2X soundbar.

The Katana V2X Soundbar is Power in a Small Package

The Sound Blaster Katana V2X is a perfectly sized solution for gamers short on space but eager to achieve some of the best audio results possible. The soundbar measures just 600mm by 95mm and has a height profile of just 62mm, which means it should fit nicely in front of, under, or behind any setup, television or otherwise.

This soundbar comes with a company subwoofer that‚Äôs 423mm tall, 250mm deep, and 116mm wide, and despite that scaled-down size factor, I found it to be a very capable piece of equipment. It adds a tasty touch of bass to the core soundbar without needing anything more than a coaxial connection to the back of the device.

Let‚Äôs talk about that sound power.

The Katana V2X soundbar boasts tri-amplified amps and represents an evolution of the earlier models of the same soundbar. It has two mid-range drivers, two tweeters, and the bolt-on subwoofer drive, all of which combine to produce a deep audio range, cinematic diversity, and stunning clarity.

It doesn‚Äôt take much to run the Katana V2X soundbar, and you can connect it to almost anything via Bluetooth 5.0, HDMI ARC, optical, aux, and USB-C. I would be blasting music via my phone in one minute, then pressing a single button and connecting to a PS5 in the next.

This multi-functional soundbar even has built-in microphones, which is a nice-to-have rather than a need-to-have. It‚Äôs all customizable too, and the sound profiles, RGB strip, and saved settings can all be tweaked.

Creative has been in the business of audio technology since 1981, and the Sound Blaster technology has been tried, tested, and optimized over many years. It‚Äôs now at a point where the Katana V2X soundbar should be considered one of the best gaming soundbars you can get for the price.

If you‚Äôre interested in the Katana V2X soundbar, it‚Äôll set you back around $259 ‚Äì $280, depending on where you buy it. I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs worth every penny, especially if you‚Äôre looking for a compact yet powerful audio solution, preferably being twinned with a TV and home console arrangement.

Let me know on the Insider Gaming Discord server if you‚Äôre interested in gaming soundbars.

item.title: PowerWash Simulator 2 Reveals 2026 Roadmap, DLC Announced
item.content:encoded:
PowerWash Simulator 2 has revealed its roadmap for 2026 ahead of its release and hints at some new free and paid DLC.

If you enjoy cozy games, PowerWash Simulator is a familiar name to all. The simple maintenance simulator took the world by storm in 2022, getting everyone to do something many hate doing: cleaning. With its huge popularity, the game teamed up with iconic IPs like Tomb Raider, Final Fantasy, and even Shrek. A sequel was announced earlier this year, with a release date revealed just this month. Now, with its release in a few hours, Futurlabs has shown off its planned roadmap for 2026, as well as how it‚Äôll spend 2025.

PowerWash Simulator Planning Three Major Paid + Free DLC in 2026, Teases Crossovers

In a post from PowerWash Simulator‚Äôs official Twitter/X account, the roadmap for 2026 is now available. As shown above, the team plans to have new paid and free DLC every quarter, starting with Q1. No specifics were given for what to expect, but the free DLC, called the Caldera Chronicles, will likely be similar to the original‚Äôs Muckingham Files. As for the paid DLC, it‚Äôll be based on other IPs, so we may see some zany crossovers like last time.

Additionally, updates to the game, including community events and costumes, will be added over time. No DLC or new content is coming out in 2025, as the team plans to focus on QoL and optimization fixes. Reviews for PowerWash Simulator 2 came out today, and, for many, it maintains the charm and fun the original did. Given how much of a sleeper hit it was, its sequel may just give it the attention it deserves. Plus, with a Day One release on Xbox Game Pass, it‚Äôs sure to keep many of us company (and make us clean freaks again).

item.title: Sonic Rumble Speeds Onto PC and Mobile in Early November
item.content:encoded:
Sonic Rumble is making its way to PC and mobile devices in early November.

The party royale game, which capitalizes on Fall Guys‚Äô success, has been in development for quite some time. Gameplay consists of players choosing their favorite Sonic characters and duking it out with others in fun and interesting mini-games. Despite positive feedback from early playtests, Sonic Rumble was met with multiple delays. Earlier this month, however, it was announced that the game would release in November. Now, we finally have the official release date, as well as a cool new trailer to debut it.

Sonic Rumble Sets November 5th, 2025 Release Date

In a short YouTube video, SEGA and Sonic Team officially reveal the release date for Sonic Rumble: November 5th. The game will launch on Steam, Google Play, and the Apple App Store, with pre-registration available now. Currently, there are no announced plans to bring the game to consoles like Nintendo Switch 2. Regardless, given its successful playtests, it may very well happen. Plus, given the popularity of similar titles like Fall Guys and the Sonic brand, it‚Äôll likely gain some attention.

The last update for Sonic Rumble provided some insight as to what the full release will look and play like. With the playtests, the development team took the feedback from fans and fine-tuned many elements. For example, the progression and rewards system is now more streamlined, as well as an overhaul of the game‚Äôs user interface and onboarding. In addition, many new features like skills and joinable Crews with friends add more to the competitive side of the title. While it has taken a while for it to arrive, Sonic Rumble will finally see the light of day, and it won‚Äôt be long until we get to see how it goes.

item.title: Taipei Game Showcase 2026 Dates, Location, and Information
item.content:encoded:
The Taipei Game Showcase 2026 is one of the first major games industry events of the 2026 calendar year, attracting hundreds of thousands of people to the Taipei Nangang Exhibition Center. In 2026, the showcase is expected to attract around 350,000 to 400,000 attendees, following last year‚Äôs event, which drew over 370,000 visitors, 400 exhibitors, and nearly 2,000 business visitors.

If you‚Äôre interested in attending the Taipei Game Showcase in Taiwan in 2026, we have everything you need to know.

Taipei Game Showcase 2026 Dates

The dates for the Taipei Game Showcase 2026 have been confirmed to take place from January 29 to February 1, 2026.

Taipei Game Showcase 2026 Location

Taipei Game Showcase 2026 is scheduled to take place at the Taipei Nangang Exhibition Center Hall 1 in Taiwan.

The address for Taipei Nangang Exhibition Center, Hall 1 is No. 1, Jingmao 2nd Rd., Nangang District, Taipei, Taiwan, with the closest airports to the event being the Taipei Songshan Airport (TSA) and Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport (TPE).

Taipei Songshan Airport (TSA) is closer for domestic and regional flights, while Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport (TPE) is the leading international hub for most international arrivals. The TSA is approximately 3km from the event, whereas the TPE is around 30km.

When Can I Get Taipei Game Showcase 2026 Tickets?

Ticket information for Taipei Game Showcase 2026 can be found over on the event‚Äôs official website here.

Overall, Taipei Game Showcase is a fantastic event for everyone to attend, and if the long journey is something you‚Äôre comfortable with, it‚Äôs definitely a bucket-list event that we‚Äôd recommend you attend.
